CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 4, 1951, pg. 1, reads: "Negroes Not Served." Portions of accompanying article read: "...While a waitress, alerted when Charles (Teenie) Harris and I [the author] appeared at the Ideal Restaurant, 2306 E. Carson Street, and took seated at the counter, scurried into the kitchen with the receiver end of a wall telephone to summon police, the cook shuffled out and made it very plain to us that Negroes simply could not get service over the counter...Earlier Wednesday, Acting Superintendent of Police Andrew Charles answering the charges of the five youths who claimed that the two Negro members of the party, Dorsey Robinson, 18, of 2401 Bedford Avenue, and Kenneth Gloster, 14, 2127 Chauncey Drive, were refused service, and then abused and arrested by the officer they summoned to uphold the law, handed this writer a report written by the officer Russell Meyer. Meyer branded Robinson, Gloster and their three white companions, Steve Feltovich, 16; Robert Horner, 15, and John Mandrillo, 17, as disciples of communism, and said that he arrested four of them because of  'their belligerent and insolent attitudes and misconduct.'..."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of four young men, possibly including Dorsey Robinson, Kenneth Gloster, Steve Feltovich, Robert Horner, or John Mandrillo, refused service at Ideal Lunch, Carson Street, South Side
